column2: The Dai-Katana is one of the most terrifying weapons on Nirn, capable of effortlessly shearing through enemy armour and lines of troops when wielded by a fine swordsmen. This drill yard is equipped with a few such master swordsmen, who train younger warriors in the ways of wielding this weapon to maximal effect.

The bow is a very popular weapon among the Akaviri, who can use it to tremendous effect in battles to pick off enemy officers or mages, and cover advancing allies. This fletcher produces a variety of high-quality arrows to keep local archers well-supplied for combat.

Many Akaviri troops are skilled with the spear, partially because of its usefulness in defending against hostile Tsaesci raids, but also for covering friendly archers. A squad of spearmen are housed at these quarters, and constantly train in defensive tactics to protect their settlement and allied troops from cavalry and infantry.

Education is considered especially important in the culture of the Altmer, and teachers are among the most respected members of Altmer society. This school is dedicated to the instruction of local students in matters such as history, language, religion, poetry, music, calligraphy, etiquette and the arcane arts. Some of the faculty are capable mages and will fight for their liege if necessary.
A shrine dedicated to Azura, Daedric Prince of dusk and dawn.
A shrine dedicated to Boethiah, Daedric Prince of deceit, treachery, conspiracy and sedition.
A shrine dedicated to Clavicus Vile, Daedric Prince of wishes and trickery.
A shrine dedicated to Hermaeus Mora, Daedric Prince of memory and knowledge.
A shrine dedicated to Hircine, Daedric Prince of the hunt and father of the werebeasts.
A shrine dedicated to Jyggalag, Daedric Prince of order and logic.
A shrine dedicated to Malacath, Daedric Prince of the spurned and the ostracized.
A shrine dedicated to Mehrunes Dagon, Daedric Prince of destruction, revolution, change, energy and ambition.
A shrine dedicated to Mephala, Daedric Prince of sex, murder and secret.
A shrine dedicated to Meridia, Daedric Prince of life and bane of the undead.
A shrine dedicated to Molag Bal, Daedric Prince of domination and father of the vampires.
A shrine dedicated to Namira, Daedric Prince of darkness and disgust.
A shrine dedicated to Nocturnal, Daedric Prince of night and shadows.
A shrine dedicated to Peryite, Daedric Prince of the natural order and pestilence.
A shrine dedicated to Sanguine, Daedric Prince of hedonism and debauchery.
A shrine dedicated to Sheogorath, Daedric Prince of madness.
A shrine dedicated to Vaermina, Daedric Prince of dreams and nightmares.

No culture is known to place a greater emphasis on magical warfare than the Altmer. Their mages are renowned both for their unusual natural talents, and the excellent quality of their training. Magical warriors of varying types are housed and trained here.
A small bowyer making bows in small quantities for your archers.
This place can supply you with as many bows as your forces would need.
A small archery range allowing missile troops to practice for the inevitability of war.
A bigger range allows for more archers to practice together and as a unit.

The best and the brightest Argonian warriors are master infantry and battlemages hardened by rigorous training and constant fighting. This edifice is less a barracks and more a dining hall where the finest warriors meet in-between training sessions.

This sparse ring of fortified huts encircles the outskirts of the local settlement to provide lodging for the constant patrols that lurk in the shadows. In the event of a siege, they can screen enemy attackers and buy the settlement critical time.

One of the reasons that the Argonians have enjoyed such success as guerrilla fighters is because of their affinity for magic, which allows them to rain Destruction spells down upon hapless foes while keeping a distance. This range offers Argonian mages a place to hone their craft in tandem with archers, who are trained to complement them by providing covering fire.

In Argonian armies, spearmen act as the first line of defence against charging cavalry, and form the backbone of most Argonian formations. A drill yard affords spearmen with an adequate training space, so that they can make the most of their free time and practice with this simple but effective weapon.

Argonian armies are foot-based, and favour light troop types over heavy ones. This barracks provides a living space for various infantry warriors, most of whom are lightly-armed yet rugged and archers.
A small armourer's shop able to make enough armour at a time that it can outfit a large party of adventurers but not an army or a castle.
An armourer's shop big enough to supply your castle with armour.
With enough armourers working in it, this place can outfit a small army with armour in no time.

A master smith is employed here, producing exceptional pieces of armour for elite troops and officers. This smith also instructs the other smiths on a variety of techniques to improve their efficiency and quality.

Ever since their ouster from the Heartland, the Ayleids have abandoned their ancient ways of using heavily-armoured warriors, instead favouring lightly-armoured mages and long-range archers. This barracks houses Ayleid archers and mages who are trained to use their abilities to complement their respective strengths on the battlefield.

Meteoric glass and iron are Aetherial materials with considerable magical capabilities. They are difficult to work with, but the Ayleids are adept in unlocking their potential. Meteoric glass and iron are studied and shaped into powerful artifacts such as Welkynd stones at this forge. The products can be applied in many ways to improve military capabilities. The skilled individuals who work with these materials can also use them to great effect when called into combat.
Barracks are where you house your loyal soldiers during times of peace.
An enlarged barracks can accommodate even more of your loyal soldiers to defend your lands or invade foreign ones.
Bath rooms built in your castle will allow your subjects working in the castle to be more clean
A small public bathhouse where people gather to clean themselves and also to socialize.
A medium sized public bathhouse where people gather to clean themselves and also to socialize.
A large bathhouse where people gather to clean themselves and also to socialize.
A baths complex is not just a large bathhouse, as it also includes saunas, massage rooms and relaxation therapies.

In keeping with the Green Pact, traditional Bosmer arrows are not made of graht-oak wood, but use materials such as ivory. Artisans in this fletcher's workshop produce a vast quantity of speciality arrows according to ancient Bosmer techniques. This keeps the local archers well-armed.

The Greenspeakers are Bosmer with the magical training to turn humble saplings into the massive graht-oaks that Bosmer settlements are based around. The Greenspeakers living here can use their training to strengthen a settlement's defenses by manipulating the foliage into various structures and patterns. When at war, they can apply their more general magical skills on the battlefield.

The spear is one of the most popular weapons in Valenwood. Spears are easy to produce and replace, and are highly effective against a variety of enemies, especially cavalry troops such as those employed by powers outside of Valenwood. Bosmer spearmen train extensively in tactics designed to cover friendly archers from hostile troops.

The Jaqspurs are long-range Bosmer archers, trained to fell enemy troops well before they can pose a significant threat. These quarters house a significant force of Jaqspurs, and are equipped with shooting ranges so they can best hone their marksmanship in-between fighting.

Not all Bosmer warriors train to be archers. Many use swords, daggers, and other short-ranged weapons to great effect, especially in the cramped conditions of the Valenwood forests. Scouts reside in these quarters during times of peace, always ready to provide reconnaissance and front-line support during wartime.

Any self-respecting Breton lord or lady maintains a fighting force of local mages, whose natural talents are honed by training and study. These quarters house a group of battle-trained mages whose abilities can demolish hostile forces in short order.
Breton martial tradition places a heavy emphasis on use of both magic and Knights, with the local Breton nobility contributing to the bulk of the latter.
A bridge, usually accompanied by a moat, restricts the ways the enemy can get into the castle and bottleneck the ones attacking the gates.
A draw bridge can be raised in the event of a siege to prevent the enemy from storming through the gates and leaving them on the other bank.

The College of Winterhold is a school for magick in the city of Winterhold. The campus is large and fortress-like in appearance. The buildings are separated by a central courtyard and various walkways. It functions much like the Mages' Guild in other parts of Tamriel, except in its being a singular and completely independent establishment.

A knight who rides on an unarmoured horse is a vulnerable knight, no matter how heavy their own armour may be. Here, several specialists produce hefty quantities of top-quality barding for horses, to give knights an edge in combat.

The noble warriors of Colovia place an incredible amount of emphasis on equestrianism, and spend accordingly high sums to take care of their horses. These stables provide luxurious accommodations for a large number of local war horses, helping the castle maintain a sizeable knightly cavalry force.

Not all horses are afforded fine stables, but these enclosed pasture lands are larger than normal and feature a well-trained team of breeders and caretakers who ensure that all the local horses are healthy and in fighting shape.

Partly due to terrain and partly due to a history full of raids, skirmishes and border wars, the Colovians possess what is among the finest cavalry in all of Tamriel. This complex houses horsemen and their steeds, who can be called into battle to shatter enemy lines with devastating charges.

Among the Colovians, equestrianism is an activity practised at all levels of society. A few retired knights are employed here, offering their knowledge to the less-wealthy men and women-at-arms so that even they can make a decisive difference on the battlefield.

Crystal Tower, or Crystal-Like-Law is a mystical structure located on the isle of Summerset, which, like White-Gold, was created in imitation of the Aedric Ada-Mantia. Considered the heart and soul of the Altmeri homeland, it was heavily warded and protected, with access to the tower being limited to two specially attuned keepers from the College of Sapiarchs. It was said to exist in every realm simultaneously, including the various planes of Oblivion.
A curtain wall is a defensive wall built outside the main wall with some distance between them. This one is formed of palisades.
A curtain wall is a defensive wall built outside the main wall with some distance between them. This one is made of stone.

Ada-Mantia, also known as the Adamantine Tower, Direnni Tower, or Ur-Tower, is believed to be the oldest building in Tamriel, if not the entirety of Nirn. During the creation of Nirn, and thus the Mundus itself, the Aedra created this structure to hold Convention, a dictate deciding the fate of both Lorkhan and the Mundus itself when the former's supposed trickery was revealed. Due to its Aedric nature and stabilizing influence upon the Mundus, it was oft copied in construction and purpose. While not of Altmer make, it became known as Direnni Tower through its tenure as the seat of the named eponymous Altmer dynasty, which ruled High Rock in ages past in the form of the Direnni Hegemony, before their power was broken against the Alessians at Glenumbra Moors.
Small docks for ships to dock in, supplying a small fleet for the local liege.
A shipwright has been built, allowing for more ships to be built and supplied to the local liege.
The local docks have been expanded so that more ships can dock there, forming a small navy.
A wharf has been set up so that more ships can dock in a smaller area.
The dock has been expanded even further, allowing for a fair sized navy to be supplied to the local liege.

There are four martial disciplines that govern traditional Velothi military culture - sword, spear, bow and magic. Here, fighters of all four types are housed, outfitted and trained in the time-honoured ways of their ancestors.

An animonculory is an automated manufactory that produces the mechanized forces to supplement Dwemer armies in battle. This facility is capable of churning out huge numbers of automatons to rapidly replenish the ranks of the Dwemer armies.

Ballistae are slow-moving and harmless in close quarters, but utterly devastating at long range, especially if they have a clear line of sight. This yard is designed to store an additional complement of ballistae.

Fire traps, swinging gates, spinning blades and other nightmarish contraptions await any adventurer or invader who dares to step foot in the defensive tunnels of this castle. These traps make sieges significantly more painful for attacking armies to carry out.

Many Dwemer are skilled in magic, and while not all possess the talents of the Tonal Architects, many are still more than powerful enough to use their spells in combat. These quarters house a team of mages skilled with a variety of combat-oriented magic.

The spear is one of the favorite weapons of Dwemer infantry. A line of spears can easily protect the narrow subterranean passageways from invaders, but can also defend important positions and protect against cavalry charges in the open field. These quarters provide weapon storage and a place for spearmen to live and train.

Dwemer Spheres are powerful automatons that specialize in close-quarters combat. They are surprisingly nimble and fairly well-armoured. This yard is dedicated to the storage of an additional complement of Spheres.

Small and agile, Dwemer Spiders lack the power of heavier automatons but can still be dangerous against unwary opponents. This yard is designed to store an additional complement of mechanized Spiders.
A small area for soldiers to exercise and keep in condition for combat.
A medium sized area for exercising to keep the local levy in good shape for marching and combat.
A large sized exercising area for soldiers to be in the best physical state for combat and moving between points.

Archery is especially significant to Falmer culture, due to the renown of Auri-El's Bow. Consequently, many Falmer nobles train in the ways of archery, and are expert sharpshooters whose pride and valour help to instil confidence in friendly troops. This range is reserved for noble archers to meet, train, and hold contests of skill.

The Falmer have long used the spear as one of their primary weapons. A wall of spears provides excellent cover for archers and mages alike, both of which are favoured troops in Falmer armies. Noble warriors tirelessly train at these grounds, hoping that their skills can help protect their allies and vanquish their enemies in battle.

The Paragon Gate is a Falmer innovation that allows an individual to instantly teleport from one location to another without need of a mage's assistance. Levy troops from the countryside can suddenly travel to the castle to muster, or can appear on the walls to bolster the local defences.
A small farm for sustaining your castle.
With more land to sow and more hands in the field you get even more produce.
Now covering much of the land and housing a host of farmers your farms not only sustain your castle but they are also a reliable source of income.
Murder holes are holes in the ceiling of a gateway the defenders can use to fire projectiles or pour oil on to the enemy below.
Pots containing oil which can be boiled and then poured down through the murder holes and on to the enemies attacking the gate.
A bastion is an angular structure projecting outward from the walls so as to allow projectiles fired from atop it to several directions.
A ballista is a large crossbow like missile weapon that fires spear-sized projectiles.
A large room where gamblers gather to play their chosen game.
A small gambling den with guards ready to handle any dispute.
A medium gambling den that can house more souls who'd like to try their luck.
A larger gambling den allows even more people to come and gamble.
People come to this huge complex to gamble from all over your realm and even beyond making it a major and steady source of income for you.
A gatehouse is a defensive building atop the gates, covering the gates and the gateway.
Castle gates now have a portcullis that can quickly be raised or lowered, providing an additional layer of defence.
Towers on both side of the gatehouse will give the enemy a hard time reaching the gates with their battering ram.

Green-Sap is a large network of Graht-oaks, giant migrating trees that are home to Bosmer cities. Each of them are reflections of each other, and every single one of them is the 'true' Green-Sap. Following the fall of Cyrod to the nascent Alessian rebellion, many Ayleids fled to Valenwood, where some may yet survive. One such refugee, the Ayleid Arch-Mage Anumaril, attempted to corrupt Green-Sap to turn it into a copy of White-Gold with a fragment of the Staff of Towers. His efforts, though unsuccessful, resulted in one particular part of Green-Sap being rooted permanently in Elden Grove, later becoming known as the First, or Great Tree.
A small quarters reserved for castle's guards, who keep the order in the castle and defend it when it is under attack.
A bigger quarters given to your guards means you can house more of them
You are able to house a huge force of guards with even more space given to them.
Guard towers not only house your guards but they are also fortified buildings that makes part of your defences.
This house contains a healing mage that spends their days healing soldiers and populace.
The house has been supplied equipment by the local governance to allow the tender to give surgeries.
A small hospital has been built, allowing for a few doctors to take in multiple patients and use healing magick and practical work.
The hospital has been upgraded to house more doctors and a few nurses, allowing for more patients to be taken in.
A large hospital has been built, housing man doctors and nurses to assist in the healing of injured soldiers and local peasants.
A small hut used by your hunters.
A hunters' lodge you use when you take a break from courtly matters and go hunting.

Ever since the rise of Reman's Empire, the cultures of Cyrodiil have embraced the conventions of the Legion, which relies on well-disciplined light and heavy troops to achieve success. These quarters are home to a fighting force of Legionnaires whose broad skills and excellent equipment make them dangerous to virtually any enemy.

The battlemage is a staple of Imperial fighting forces, bolstering friendly troops and weakening hostile ones with spells before joining the fray, weapon in hand. This barracks maintains a small company of versatile, powerful battlemages.

As an Imperial castle grows, so to does its need for battlemages. This tower provides a variety of amenities for local mages, who are constantly studying to improve their magical abilities in the event of war.

Many Imperial horses are not bred specifically for war, but even horses used as beasts of burden are bred so that they are not a liability on the battlefield. This large paddock is attended to by handlers who focus on keeping local steeds combat-ready.
The Imperial Prison is the dungeon of the Imperial City and one of the larger prisons in Tamriel. A veritable fortress, almost impossible to break out of... or so they claim.

Cavalry is a prominent component of the average Imperial army, supplementing slower heavy infantry in a variety of roles. This barracks provides lodging and basic stable services for numerous local cavalry troops.
Quality saddles improve the overall combat performance of cavalry. This workshop provides customized saddles to cavalry troops, especially those who otherwise would not be able to afford their own.

Scouts and patrol forces can provide reconnaissance that slower infantry are unable to offer, and help screen enemy forces during battles so that the infantry may close in unscathed. A few squadrons of scouts keep their horses at these stables, and are ready to lend their skills at a moment's notice.
Spears and lances are specialty items in an Imperial fighting force, used almost exclusively for cavalry. This smithy is devoted to their production, to help maximize the power of cavalry charges.

Due to the mountainous terrain of their homeland, most Kamal opt to fight as infantry, carrying heavy arms and armour into battle. This barracks houses a group of ferocious fighters who are skilled with swords, spears, and other infantry weapons.

Many Kamal nobles eschew fighting on horseback in favour of fighting on foot. They are ferocious, tenacious and merciless warriors and delight in bloody combat. A group of noble warriors is housed here, always eager to fight.
A small hall to house the throne of the local liege.
The hall has been expanded to allow more housing for those in the court.
A large hall for the local liege and their court.
A small keep has been built up around the hall, providing for more of a garrison.
The keep has been expanded, allowing for more of a garrison to live in and defend.
The keep has been expanded further, allowing for a good size of garrison to live in.
A small citadel for the protection of the local court, providing a sizeable garrison.
A medium citadel for the protection of the local court, providing a large, skilled garrison.
A large citadel for the protection of the local court, providing a huge, elite garrison.
The local castle is supported by a citadel, heralded as one of the largest, most defensible fortress in the local county. It would be a true task to capture it.

Given their dexterity and intellects on par with those of men and elves, the Khajiit who fight as cavalry are armoured more like infantry than beasts of burden. This facility produces armour that is custom-fitted to the needs of individual Khajiit.

Unlike the other peoples of Tamriel, the Khajiit do not use horses or other beasts for their cavalry. Instead, they rely on four of their quadrupedal phases - the Pahmar, Pahmar-Raht, Senche and Senche-Raht. This barracks offers living quarters for light and heavy "cavalry" alike.

Khajiit cavalry are fully trained in how to use basic weaponry. While their four-legged gaits make most weapons impractical, certain weapons can be attached to their helmets or mounted on their shoulders, making them all the more dangerous.

This building offers additional training to Pahmar and Pahmar-Raht, quadrupedal Khajiit who are larger and stronger than the average human or elf. They are not large enough to carry a rider into battle, but are fast and powerful enough fill the niche of light cavalry. They excel in ambushes and pursuit, and are deadly in a pitched battle.

This building provides additional training to Senche and Senche-Raht, the massive, quadrupedal Khajiit who carry other Khajiit into battle. They fight as heavy cavalry, engaging enemy cavalry and charging into battle lines, where their might and ferocity rapidly demoralize enemy troops.
This is tower is reserved for your battlemages for their accommodation and it is also where they practice their magick when they are not in battle blasting enemy soldiers.
With their tower extended, more battlemages can be housed.
With their tower extended, more battlemages can be housed.
A library has been added to your mage tower where your mages can read and improve their knowledge of the arcane while they are off duty.
An arcanaeum with a vast collection of books, both common and rare, is now at the disposal of your mages.
The palace of the Mane of Elsweyr, where he commands over his subjects.

Due to the overbearing warmth of Pyandonea, many Maormer fight lightly armed and armoured so as not to be overly fatigued during combat. Archers and light infantry trained in jungle warfare tactics are housed and outfitted at this barracks.

The snake magick that the Maormer practice allows them to charm and train vicious serpents into loyal guardians, beasts of burdens and mounts for their elite warriors. Here, a group of snake mages ply their craft to provide battle-ready serpents. These mages are also capable fighters and can assist in battle.
An office containing officers that work on organizing the local army.
An office controlling the distribution of supplies, and demands of the army.
The headquarters of the local army, controlling all facets of logistics and administration.
A moat is a deep and wide ditch around your hold that will slow down the invaders.
The moat has been dug deeper, trapping invaders inside unless they have ladders, forcing them to find other ways.
The moat, now flooded with water, will force the enemy to either take the bridges or build some themselves.
A small mustering ground for the local levy to organize when called to war.
A medium mustering ground for the local levy to organize when called to war.
A large mustering ground for the local levy to organize when called to war.
A huge mustering ground for the local levy to organize when called to war.

The most respected of the dead are entombed in this imposing necropolis. The colossal, vaulted main chamber and numerous personal burial rooms contain the most powerful and dreaded undead warriors. Their battleaxes, greatswords and other mighty weapons make quick work of all but the most skilled opponents.

The Nibenese are the proud innovators of the Battlemage, a soldier devoted to both esoteric arcane studies and traditional military disciplines. Battlemages train and rest at this barracks, ready to be called into combat so that they may show off their impressive powers.

The Nibenese hold their battlemages in the highest esteem, regarding them as the decisive element of their armies. This tower is built specifically to house the best and brightest scholar-soldiers, whose flamboyant style of warfare belies the terrifying levels of damage they can unleash on the battlefield.

The mead hall is at the centre of the average Nord adventurer's life. It is a forum to boast of achievements, a proving ground for tests of might, and a community hall for feasting and drinking. This mead hall attracts an array of aspiring heroes who are eager for battle.
What the mead hall is to the great heroes of the Nords, the longhouse is to the average farmer. From these common hearths, great armies can be mustered.

Berserkers are the front-line shock troops of any self-respecting Orc army, renowned for their bloodthirsty charges and deadly combat abilities. Fearsome as they may be, they are far from an undisciplined rabble. This building is a barracks and a training center, where experienced berserkers instruct aspiring warriors on the best ways to harness their rage.

The finest fighters in the surrounding area are summoned to this hall, where they can boast in meaningful company or prove their mettle against each other in personal combat. When called upon to fight, their prodigious combat abilities inspire their brethren to fight as well as they do.
Orc Holds of varying sizes are the small fortified settlements commonly sighted dotted around Orcish lands, or the lands of others for some reason or another.

Not every Orc warrior is destined for greatness. This small encampment on the edge of the settlement is home to lesser warriors who, for one reason for another, lack the equipment, discipline or courage to fight as heavy troops and instead act as skirmishers and raiders.

This barracks houses Orc nobles who fight on foot, clad in heavy armour and armed to the teeth. Unlike their lowborn counterparts who typically favour simpler weapons, these fighters often employ spears and halberds, and possess the training to utilize them in complex formations.
Few Orc warriors prefer to fight on horseback. These stables house the stronghold's small squads of cavalry, which are nonetheless effective in screening enemy forces and running down fleeing troops.
A paddock is an enclosure, usually just outside the stables, where horses can exercise.
A medium-sized paddock allows for the exercise of more horses at the same time.
A large paddock allows for even more horses to exercise at the same time.

Magic is always devastating on the battlefield, especially when wielded by those who are naturally adept in the arcane arts, such as the Po Tun. This barracks hosts a small fighting force of mages who can supplement an army with a bevy of spells.
This is where the castle's archers are accommodated.
This is where the castle's archers are accommodated.
This is where the castle's archers are accommodated.
Infantry quarters are where your infantry troops eat, live and sleep.
Infantry quarters are where your infantry troops eat, live and sleep.
Infantry quarters are where your infantry troops eat, live and sleep.
Infantry quarters are where your infantry troops eat, live and sleep.
Infantry quarters are where your infantry troops eat, live and sleep.
Infantry quarters are where your infantry troops eat, live and sleep.
Riders' quarters are where you house your cavalrymen
Riders' quarters are where you house your cavalrymen
Riders' quarters are where you house your cavalrymen
Riders' quarters are where you house your cavalrymen
Riders' quarters are where you house your cavalrymen

The bow is a favourite weapon among the Quey, and many of them are skilled archers. This building offers advanced training facilities for bowmen, and hosts contests where they can prove their mettle against one another.

Although simplistic, the war canoe is an extremely cost-effective and practical ship for the shallow waters of the Quey islands. This complex includes space for a shipwright, as well as docking for a large complement of war canoes.

Not every Reachman who pledges to fight is trained or outfitted like a noble warrior. Nonetheless, their ferocity makes even lesser Reachman warriors deadly foes, skilled in hit-and-run tactics and superb at launching ambushes. This is a small camp constructed just outside the castle walls, where lightly-armoured fighters live and train.

The history of the Reachmen is fraught with conflict. In order to defend against raids and sieges, they have devised countless measures that are cheap, dependable and effective, such as this redoubt system. Walls of blinds, sharpened stakes and hidden traps render these structures difficult to take and very useful for prolonging sieges.

Many Reachman troops eschew the use of horses and heavy armour and instead opt to enter battle carrying light armour, wielding bows, spells and light weaponry. These quarters house the type of fighters who have battled to protect the mountain strongholds of the Reach for millennia.

Many skilled Redguard warriors are self-employed wanderers and adventurers, and are difficult to recruit, but well worth the effort of employing. This hall is both a meeting place and administration center where freelancing fighters can join the ranks of a noble lord's armies for fame, glory and gold.

Cavalry swords are most effective if they are longer than infantry swords, due to the elevation of mounted troops and the extra leverage that they have with such weapons. This smithy is devoted to the production of sabers, scimitars and other swords that are designed specifically for Redguard mounted troops.

Resilient, nimble, quick-witted horses are the type most suited to Redguard cavalry warfare. Professional horse breeders reside at this complex. They oversee the breeding and training of steeds to ensure that they are of the highest possible quality, and their skills result in a greater quantity of available horses.
While many Redguard cavalry troops prefer light armour, there are some noble fighters who favour heavy armament. These stables are maintained specifically for gallantly Redguard combatants.

The adventurous Redguards are well-known for their spectacular martial skills, but prefer speed and mobility in most of their troop types rather than raw power and heft. The Redguard horsemen housed here charge into battle clad in light armour and brandishing sabers and scimitars. Enemies that aren't hewn down in the thick of battle are usually run down afterwards.

Many Redguard cavalry troops operate primarily as scouts, and are responsible relaying messages, transporting materials, providing reconnaissance and screening enemy troops. However, they can and do fight on the front lines when needed. This stable houses and outfits a large number of such cavalry.
Armoury is where arms and armour are held when not used by your men.
A small depot where some supplies for your armed forces are stored.
Quartermaster supervises stores and handles the distribution of supplies within your army.
A field headquarters used by your retinue commanders.
A large supply depot, in which you can find any military supplies in abundant quantities, in use by your men.
A small riding ground where your cavalry troops ride their horses.
A medium-sized riding ground where your cavalry troops ride their horses
With a large riding ground, more of your cavalrymen can ride their horses at the same time.
Saddler is where saddles for use by your cavalry are made.

As a seafaring people, the Maormer are uniquely focused on maritime innovations. This dock includes an enclosed rookery where large sea serpents, each capable of transporting small armies, are bred, trained and charmed with Maormer snake magick in order to serve as makeshift sea vessels. A standard shipwright and space for ordinary ships are also included.
A small smithy where some metalworks for your castle is done.
A medium sized smithy allows for more diverse metalwork to be done.
This is where all of the metalwork is done for your castle.
With a smithing manufactory you produce enough metalwork to supply not only your castle, but also the neighbouring regions.
A small spearmaker making pikes, spears and lances in small numbers, to be used by your soldiers.
A spearmaker is where spears, pikes and lances are made for use by your forces.

The Tang Mo possess superb alacrity, which they use to great effect in combat. This is a loose ring of light infantry camps set up outside the castle. When the troops here spot attackers, they will make a hasty retreat through hidden passages to arrive at the castle and bolster its defences.

The sling is a simple but effective weapon with excellent range and accuracy when used by a well-trained individual. Tang Mo slingers are trained here, able to unleash barrage after barrage of stones and metal shot that can quickly whittle down enemy forces from a distance.

Many Tang Mo fighters employ hit-and-run ambush tactics to wear down enemy armies. The fighters trained at this barracks are experts in ambushes, raids and guerrilla tactics. They rely entirely upon light weaponry and wear only basic armour, but are nonetheless dangerous foes.
A room in your castle where people gather to have a few drinks.
A small public tavern for people to visit and drink away their woes.
A good-sized tavern that caters to both the castle staff and the general public.
A large tavern, providing a variety of drinks and social opportunities to its patrons.
